The statements below are followed by two conclusions labeled I and II. Assuming that the information in the statements is true, even if it appears to be at variance with generally established facts, decide which conclusion(s) logically and definitely follow(s) from the information given in the statements.

Statements
1. Some cats are goats.
2. All goats are cows.

Conclusions
I. All cows are goats.
II. Some cats are cows.

option.option: Both conclusions I and II follow
Either conclusion I or II follows

Read the given passage carefully and select the best answer to each question out of the four given alternatives.

Vedanta summarises the metaphysics of the Upanishads, a clutch of Sanskrit religious texts, likely written between 800 and 500 BCE. They form the basis for the many philosophical, spiritual and mystical traditions of the Indian sub-continent. The Upanishads were also a source of inspiration for some modern scientists, including Albert Einstein, Erwin Schrรถdinger and Werner Heisenberg, as they struggled to comprehend quantum physics of the 20th century.

The Vedantic quest for understanding begins from what it considers the logical starting point: our own consciousness. How can we trust conclusions about what we observe and analyse unless we understand what is doing the observation and analysis? The progress of AI, neural nets and deep learning have inclined some modern observers to claim that the human mind is merely an intricate organic processing machine โ and consciousness, if it exists at all, might simply be a property that emerges from information complexity. However, this view fails to explain intractable issues such as the subjective self and our experience of qualia, those aspects of mental content such as โrednessโ or โsweetnessโ that we experience during conscious awareness. Figuring out how matter can produce phenomenal consciousness remains the so-called โhard problemโ.

Which of the following do we experience during conscious awareness?
Which of the following is true as per the passage?

option.option: Modern observers give importance to consciousness.
Vedanta does not give importance to consciousness.
Both Vedanta and modern observers give importance to consciousness.

option.option: Albert Einstein and Erwin Schrรถdinger only
